Technical Analysis of Online Meeting Tool with Automatic Language Recognition
text:
In the era of globalization, attending international conferences and business negotiations has become a requirement for an increasing number of people. However, language barriers often prevent many from participating in such events. To address this issue, our team has developed an online meeting tool that automatically recognizes the language of attendees, providing high-quality simultaneous interpretation services.

Our online meeting tool is built on advanced speech recognition technology. When attendees join a meeting, our tool automatically recognizes their speech and compares the results with a pre-set language library to determine their language. Next, the tool converts the attendees' speech into the corresponding language text and performs real-time translation. Finally, the translated results are presented to other attendees through simultaneous interpretation, thus achieving the functions of automatic language recognition and simultaneous translation.

To ensure translation quality, our online meeting tool employs multiple speech recognition and translation technologies. First, we use deep learning algorithms to recognize the speech of attendees and natural language processing to perform translation. In addition, we combine various technologies such as machine translation and manual proofreading to continually optimize translation quality, ensuring the accuracy and fluency of simultaneous interpretation.

Furthermore, our online meeting tool has high adaptability and scalability. It can adapt to different network environments and speech characteristics, accommodate multiple attendees simultaneously, and support multiple languages, including Chinese, English, Japanese, and Korean.

In summary, our online meeting tool achieves the functions of automatic language recognition and simultaneous interpretation, enabling easy participation in global conferences and business negotiations. It is built on advanced speech recognition and translation technology, with high adaptability and scalability. If you are interested in our online meeting tool and would like to learn more about its technical details or discuss related technical issues with us, please leave a message below or contact us. We look forward to exchanging ideas and cooperating with you.

Ask HN: Which HN post (or comment) changed your life (or career)
text:
I'm 45 years old and I've consumed many time- (and self-) management books that suggest to avoid news and social media. In general, this is good advice.

The one exception I make is my twice-daily scan of the HN homepage, as, over the years, there have been many insightful posts, comments and links which have helped me tremendously [1]. This includes "Show HN" for tools and platforms that helped me gain an edge (Algolia, Sqreen) and comments which help to negate rabbit holes.

So, I am wondering: which posts (or insightful comments) have helped you?

[1] A big thank you to the HN moderators who ceaselessly do their best to maintain a consistent quality.

title: It's Mechanical March
Ask HN: US/Remote companies which hire people based in Australia
text:
TL;DR version: Which companies hire remote workers in Australia and pay > $135,000 (USD).

Long version:

I'm currently based in Toronto(on a work visa) but will move back to Australia as a permanent resident in May. I've worked in Australia for a couple of years before and know there's barely jobs paying over 200k AUD for DevOps Engineers/SRE, and with the hiring freeze in place at Google, Canva, Atlassian there aren't really many options. The only way to make an acceptable income is being a contractor, but that's also not too exciting.

Which companies hire people based remotely in Australia? I can adapt to time zones, so that's not an issue.

Thank you!

Show HN: A Unix timestamp converter that includes the micro and nanoseconds
text: I find myself having to convert a lot of unix timestamps to a human readable format, but most of the online calculators I found don't include the micro or nanoseconds in the human readable output. It's a small detail, but I find myself having to manually space out the timestamp frequently. I'm learning frontend development, so I made this converter to hopefully make it easier to convert timestamps. Welcome to any feedback :)

Help me find: interactive tutorial for a JavaScript scheme interpreter
text:
Does anybody remember this, posted on HN?

It was an interactive tutorial on a single page web app, where you have a code editor, some explanation for what the code is doing, and arrows to skip forward or backwards in the tutorial. You can then edit the code and see different results.

IIRC the code was in JavaScript and it created a basic lisp/scheme interpreter.

It explained succinctly concepts of tokenizing/parsing, lexing, AST, etc. with these examples.

I've googled for:

- web app showing how to build an interpreter / compiler, complete with lexer, parser, ast - hacker news interactive interpreter lexer ast tutorial javascript - hacker news writing a compiler tutorial spa interactive ast lexer tokenizer parser

with no luck.

Thank you for any help!
